item.title: Russian Ordinal Numbers
item.description: Third is an exception too, and it just keeps going. Applications It’s worth mentioning, because otherwise you might think it’s unimportant or uninteresting. You definitely need ordinal numbers for dates. For instance, we say: today is the 27th. You can get a preview in Ordinal numbers and dates in Russian (Learn Russian with Alfia, 2020, 22 m).

item.title: The Nominative Case: именительный падеж
item.description: What or who The nominative case is the unmodified or default form of a word. If nothing is being done to it in the sentence, you don’t need to do anything either.*) This is my car, the book is thick: машина and книга stay as they are.

item.title: The letter Ё
item.description: Yo The sound isn’t hard. It’s like the Yo in York, says the (English) Wikipedia . The Dutch version compares it to the jo in jokken (to fib). Russian sources often give examples like ёжик (jozhik, hedgehog) or ёлка (yolka, Christmas tree).

item.title: To have, to have, to have
item.description: у … есть Literally, a Russian doesn’t say “I have,” but rather “by me is.” For that “by,” you use у, “is” becomes есть, and in between comes the personal pronoun in the genitive ( second case ). This turns я (I) into меня.

item.title: First and Second Conjugation
item.description: It is useful – and inevitable – to learn these conjugations. The same patterns recur frequently. item.title: Counting and Numbers
item.description: The words for 1 and 2 can take different forms (respectively один, одна, одно and два or две). And when Russians count, instead of starting with один, they often begin with раз (time/once). From 10 to 20 Once you can count from 1 to 10, you can easily go further.

item.title: Masculine, Feminine, Neuter
item.description: Exceptions For every rule, there’s an exception. имя (name) and время (time) are neuter, кофе (coffee) is masculine, and there are more examples like these. And if a word ends in ь (мягкий знак, the soft sign), it can be either masculine or feminine.

item.title: Making Sentences
item.description: Word Order Cats eat mice can also be expressed in Russian as mice eat cats. There’s a lot of freedom in word order. The price for that freedom is declensions and cases. They keep sentences simple but constantly change the words.

item.title: A Piece of Cake: Russian Alphabet
item.description: Apps Starting simple is recommended. For Android users: Russian alphabet for kids is great for beginners and looks cheerful. You’ll also learn some basic words right away. Russian Alphabet is less about cheerfulness but is clear and practical. Some example words are (too) difficult for beginners.
